entry.title: The Most Cost Effective Solution for Distracted Driving
entry.summary: Humans are stupid.We tend to feel safer in a car than in an airplane, even though the statistics clearly tell…
entry.content:
Humans are stupid.

We tend to feel safer in a car than in an airplane, even though the statistics clearly tell us otherwise. We still use Facebook even though we know it is designed to be addictive. Heck, I even got you to click on this article based on a "clickbait" title and an image often used for MEMEs.

There, of course, is a raging debate over how how much control we can exert over our lives. Psychology has uncovered a lot of vulnerabilities in our reasoning and decision making. So let me ask a surprising question;

Is distracted driving really our fault? Can we be blamed for driving distracted?

The obviously answer is yes. Driving and using your phone at the same time is the single most idiotic thing you can do in a car besides Driving while Under the Influence of a drug. It shows that you do not value the health and well-being of the people around you. However, most people do care about the well-being of their friends and even strangers around them, so what gives?

Let's say you were asked to push a button for a piece of your favorite candy, but at the slight chance that your friend sitting across from you will lose their arm, would you do it? Probably not. The trade-off is clear and direct. A piece of candy is not worth injuring your friend.

The trade-off is not clear and direct for distracted driving. We feel that we are in control and we think we are competent. Changing the song on Spotify or replying to a message at a stop light does not seem like that big of a risk. The reality is much more grim.

Stop It!

Ok, so maybe you already knew that we humans are stupid. Maybe you already understand the inherent problems. But the problem still exists right? Maybe you still can't resist the urge sometimes?

There have been so many failed solutions created by tech companies and automotive manufacturers. Steering wheel hand sensors, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, gaze tracking, and driving modes that silence phone notifications have all mostly failed to solve the fundamental problem.Â 

Why? Because the tech and auto companies are totally missing the fundamental problem, the root cause, the principal instigator! The real problem is...

Automatic Transmissions

Yes, you read that correctly. Let me underline it for you.

Automatic Transmissions

The Solution!!!

That's why I designed the all new, and completely novel.... Manual Transmission!!!

This breakthrough in engineering uses bleeding edge principles from cognitive science and complex systems to design the ultimate, human-in-the-loop, anti-distracted driving control system!

Yes, you have reached the crux of this article. I am sorry to disappoint you. But if you want to understand the (non-comedic) nuances in my argument then keep reading.

I started driving a manual transmission car about two years ago now. A beautiful silver 2002 Acura RSX with a 5-speed gearbox. You know what I also stopped doing about two years ago? Driving Distracted.

When it matters most (urban environments, stop and go traffic) manual transmission vehicles require two hands and two feet to drive. Not only is your body physically engaged, your central nervous system also has to coordinate all of that action!

No longer can you stomp on the accelerator when it is time to go. You have to disengage the clutch, shift into first gear, release the brake, and then simultaneously engage the clutch and apply the accelerator. This added time helps you to become more aware of your surrounding after disengagement with your phone. Genius!

Manual transmissions are the ultimate redundant, anti-distracted driving, safety feature! What could be better?

  • Manual transmissions are cheaper than automatic transmissions

Wow, no way!! BUT WAIT,

There's MORE!!!

  • Manual transmission are more efficient that automatic transmissions (weight savings and power transfer)

YES, you get TWO for the price of one!!! the incredible price of NO MORE DISTRACTED DRIVING.

The Conspiracy

Ok, but really. How is this possible? How did we go from a manual transmission that is cheaper, more efficient, and prevents distracted driving to an automatic transmission that basically kills people and the environment.

Automatic transmissions are designed by The Devil.Â 

Lucifer is an amazing engineer. Not only is he proficient in Solidworks and ANSYS, he also keeps a focus on business strategy. Let's count the number of ways that automatic transmissions (AT) accomplish the Devil's business goals.

  1. Murder
    1. As already mentioned, ATs enable distracted driving which causes injury and death.
    2. ATs are less efficient, causing more environmental pollution and killing vulnerable populations
  2. Lust
    1. ATs only require one hand, giving you a free hand for other activities.
  3. Gluttony
    1. Road nuggets, doughnut holes, etc. Excessive eating on long trips is now within reach!
  4. Sloth
    1. By definition, ATs are targeted at users that have a "disinclination to exertion"
  5. Theft
    1. Cars with ATs are easier to steal. No knowledge of how to use a clutch needed!

Is anymore proof needed?!?

It is time to say NO to the Devil and replace your automatic transmission car with a new and improved manual transmission car! Call now!

The End

Sign this petition to Ban Automatic Transmissions!

Now on to more serious notes. While I had a lot of fun spinning this ridiculous parable-like article, I think I need to frame these thoughts in concise language.

  1. Distracted driving is a serious problem! We all know it and have done it ourselves.
  2. We are not as smart as we think we are. We need to design systems and products ahead of time with this in mind.
  3. The solution to problems is not always more technology.
  4. Easier is not always better.

You can sign a number of pledges to not drive distracted, but the best steps you can take areÂ 

  • Enable your phone's "Driving Mode" that will automatically detect when you are driving and silence notifications.
  • Enable your phone's Do Not Disturb mode while driving.
  • Pull over in a safe place off the road. Stop lights are the most common place for pedestrians and cyclists to be killed or injured!
  • Know your directions ahead of time. Do not adjust your phone's mapping/gps while driving.
  • No text is that important. Remember, everyone who crashes thinks that they can text without crashing.
  • Song choice is not that important. I bet you can guess what MEME video this links to.

And don't forget to hold your friends and family accountable.

entry.content:
This is the third article in a series about the uFarm product design process. The series delves into three distinct areas of the design process;

  1. Product | Building a useful product that actually solves problems.
  2. Aquaponics | Plant science turned into design parameters. (Coming mid-September)
  3. Engineering | Iterative design of a cyber-physical system.

The series will end with;

  1. Outcomes | Running and testing the prototype. (coming mid-September)
  2. Build Log | Pictures and comments from the process. (coming mid-September)

Table of Contents

  • System Architecture
    • Plant Productivity
    • Energy Use
    • Maintenance
    • Result
  • Parametric Design
  • Mechanical Design
    • Stress/Strain Analysis
    • Fluid Dynamics | Plumbing
  • Actuation and Control
    • Fluid Flow
      • Pump Sizing
      • Actuated Valve Choices
    • HVAC
    • Controller
  • Electrical Design
    • Light
      • Brightness
      • Designing for PPFD
    • Power/Signal Distribution
    • Component Stack
  • Software
  • Future Updates

System Architecture

There is an infinite number of ways to design an aquaponic system. This section will dive in the guiding principles, based on aquaponic science, that reduce the size of the design domain.

uFarm is heavily influenced by proven design architectures from commercial aquaponic systems. Commercial systems are designed to maximize productivity and reduce costs. The relevant optimization goals for a personal grow system roughly include

  • Maximize Plant Productivity
  • Minimize Energy Use
  • Minimize Maintenance

Plant Productivity

How do you fit the most number of plants into the smallest footprint possible? Easy, you build a vertical grow system and you space the plants as closely as possible. Productivity becomes a challenge of space optimization. Space optimization is surprisingly difficult, just ask mathematicians about circle/sphere packing. However, space can also be saved by using a single component for multiple uses. uFarm optimizes space by;

  • Using the media grow bed as a bio-filter that houses the nitrifying bacterial colony.
  • Using the pump to also aerate the water (increase dissolved oxygen)
  • Using the DWC grow bed as a water reservoir
  • Using the media bed as a particle filter for the DWC grow bed

Energy Use

Besides HVAC, the biggest energy drains are water pumps and grow lights.

Water is heavy and water pumps are inefficient. However, water pumps increase in efficiency (Litre/Watt) as pump size increases. This leads to a common design architecture called CHOP, constant height one pump. CHOP means that water is pumped from its lowest potential energy to its highest potential energy in a single place; gravity does the rest. Having a single pump also reduces maintenance and an additional pump can be added in parallel for redundancy. While a vertical grow system is obviously not at a constant height, uFarm uses only one pump for complete system recirculation.

Light is not so simple to optimize. Generally speaking there are two system design concerns for lighting, uniformity and heat. Lighting uniformity can be improved by using lenses or diffusers, both of which have downsides. Lighting uniformity can also be increased by increasing the number of light sources, such as LED strips or arrays.Â 

Every light source also produces heat (radiated and convected) that needs to be managed. Convective heat transfer methods (big fans) are commonly used to move hot air out of the grow area and prevent tip burn caused by radiated heat. Because height is limited in vertical growing (tip burn is a concern), LEDs and florescents are commonly used because they emit less infrared radiation.Â 

Maintenance

The most labor intensive maintenance is cleaning. There are three ways to reduce maintenance cost/time.

  1. Design for easy cleaning
    1. make system easy to disassemble or access areas that need cleaned
  2. Design to reduce frequency of cleaning
    1. Limit light exposure to prevent algae and other unwanted/harmful growth
    2. Increase size of the particle filter
  3. Design for self-cleaning
    1. Add vermiculture to the particle filter to break down physical waste
    2. Add bottom feeders, such as plecostomus, to manage algae growth

Result

The engineering principles/constraints were mingled with product specifications over a few iterations of product sketches and parametric studies. Ultimately the architecture seen below was chosen for the initial prototype.

Parametric Design

Defining the overall direction for system architecture is an iterative process. Parametric design allows each iteration to be analyzed and optimized more quickly. There are well over a hundred quantitative parameters that can be defined for a vertical aquaponic system. Therefore, constraints need to be applied to reduce the number of free parameters. A simplified equation-based approach was taken for the prototype design that used the following variables.

Mechanical Design

Â 

Stress/Strain Analysis

There is nothing too novel about the mechanical loading analysis. An "off the shelf" heavy-duty rack was used as the main support structure. This rack came with a per shelf maximum load of 800lbs (or 4000lbs total load) of "evenly distributed weight". I contacted the manufacturer to get more details on how this load rating was determined, but they were unable to provide any reasoning (or safety factors). A shelf system is an over-constrained system, so simple analysis could not be conducted to verify their load rating or determine a safety factor.

Luckily, the aquaponic system design does approximately distribute its weight evenly, so no further stress analysis was deemed necessary (I was really hoping to apply some principles from statics here).

However, strain is a large concern. The heavy duty rack is made of metal beams and particle board shelves. These components have relatively low Young's moduli (stiffness) when compared to the glass of the fish tank. This means that the shelf will sag (strain) a greater amount than the fish tank which leads to uneven support of the tank. This is bad because the fish tank design assumes uniform support around the edges, which is critical to reduce stress concentrations. Traditional tempered glass does not bend well! Therefore, additional support was added to increase the stiffness. A strain constrained analysis found that 2x4 wood beams would reduce the mid point sag to <1mm. This was deemed acceptable without redoing the fish tank analysis/design.

A fish tank is also an over-constrained system. Unlike the shelf system, there are publicly available finite element modelling efforts to determine areas of max stress/strain in a glass aquarium. Max strain can be reduced by using a commonly used technique called cross-bracing, where a cross support is added to the middle of the tank. There are downsides to cross bracing which include poor aesthetics and reduced tank access for cleaning and management. There is another commonly used method of reducing max strain called euro-bracing, where thin, perpendicular strips of glass are added to the top rim of the tank. This uses the same principle as an I-beam to increase the second moment of area (increase equivalent stiffness). Euro-bracing was used for mostly aesthetic reasons.

Â 

Fluid Dynamics | Plumbing

Out of all the areas of engineering science, fluid dynamics is the least understood. Many of the design tools use empirical relationships that have fairly large margins of error.

The are a number of simplifications and assumptions that need to be made to analyze the plumbing requirements of the prototype. As designed, the prototype is non-pressurized and frequently switches between open channel and regular pipe flow. This means that there will be significant changes in fluid flow rate as the pipe transitions between open channel and pipe flow, however maximum flow rate is determined by the pipe flow regime.

Since the system is not pressurized the maximum rate of fluid flow in the pipe flow regime is determined by gravity (change in height) and is significantly impacted by friction losses within the pipe/tube. Therefore, the Darcy-Weisbach equation was used to determine the minimum diameter pipe that would satisfy the flow rate requirements from the parametric design stage. Because Darcy-Weisbach is an implicit function for pipe diameter, an iterative analysis approach was implemented via a spreadsheet.

Another point of consideration is pipe fouling due to biological growth. This will increase the equivalent "surface roughness" of the pipe over time which will in turn decrease the maximum flow rate. Therefore it is safer to oversize the pipe, or use a larger safety factor.

Once a reasonable pipe diameter is determined, fittings can be chosen so that the plumbing system is easy to put together and remains water tight. This is not a fun process as there are a variety of materials, thread standards, and fitting types.

  • Material that is rated for "cold" potable water is the ideal choice. Certifications depend on country, e.g. NSF-61
  • Flexible tubing (LLDPE or Vinyl) is easier to route than rigid piping (PVC)
  • NPT is the common standard for PVC pipe fittings in the U.S.. Barb fittings are the cheapest for flexible (non-pressurized) tubing

Actuation and Control

Fluid Flow

Control of fluid flow is achieved with a submerged pump and direct action solenoid valves.

Pump Sizing

Pump sizing is based on the desired flowrate and head (the height at zero pressure). A good pump curve will give the relationship between flowrate and head while plotting constant efficiency and power curves, although these specifications can be hard to find at pumps targeted at consumers (less than 1HP or 1kW).

Based on the height of the grow system and the estimated losses from friction in the pipe and fittings, the pump head was determined to be approximately 10 feet and the minimum flowrate determined by parametric design was 100 gallons per hour (3 meters at 400 litres per hour). Again, pump fouling from biological growth can reduce pump performance

Actuated Valve Choices

  • Solenoid Valve
    • There are a variety of solenoid valves targeted at a range of different fluid types and pressures. Nearly all solenoid valves are fully on or fully off and come in "normally open" and "normally closed" configurations. For non-pressurized liquid, direct action valves are the best option, although their energy requirements are much larger. Be wary of the cheapest solenoid valves that are generally designed for pressurized fluid (40-60psi).
  • Ball Valve
    • These are traditional ball valves with an added stepper motor that can adjust the rate of fluid flow through the valves. These things are expensive.

HVAC

There is minimal HVAC engineering in this prototype. While temperature and humidity are important growing parameters, the cost to implement a full HVAC system is prohibitive. However, this system is designed for use in a temperature and humidity controlled environment, an apartment. When combining thermal output from grow lights and humidity from transpiration and evaporation, rudimentary temperature and humidity manipulation is possible using simple ventilation with the cooler, less humid apartment air. Limited HVAC was implemented using a cheap temperature and humidity sensor (the AM2302), a few computer fans, and a simple bang-bang control algorithm.

Controller

All of the components mentioned so far require binary control; they are either on or off. Control of these components can be achieved with an array of low voltage relays and a micro-controller (like an Arduino).Â 

Light control is not binary. Additional AC dimmers were added to control the brightness of the grow lights. The AC dimmers use pulse skip modulation to modify the AC sine waves transferred to the LEDs and are controlled via pulse width modulation from a micro-controller or other real-time control device.

Because system parameters do not change much, open-loop control works fairly well. However some water level sensors are added for additional safety in preventing overflow conditions and detecting leaks.

Electrical Design

Light

As mentioned in the introduction, there are a number of considerations when designing lighting for an indoor grow system.

  • The light needs to be bright enough to maximize grow.
  • The light brightness needs to be variable to control growth
  • The spectral power distribution of the light needs to be variable to control growth
  • Lighting needs to be uniform so that growth is even
  • Radiated heat needs to be removed to prevent issues like tip burn, this is done by adjust grow light height and providing adequate ventilation

Brightness

Brightness is a complicated topic that has been oversimplified in the public domain to mean Watts or Lumens. Brightness is actually a perceived phenomena that depends on the emission spectrum of a light source and the sensitivity of a receiver/sensor. Brightness for humans is not the same as brightness for plants. Therefore we need a more neutral way to measure light, such as density of photons per area.

  • Micromols (Âµmol) - measurement of the number of photons
  • Photosynthetic Active Radiation (PAR) - radiation that is used by plants for photosythesis, generally wavelengths of 400-700nm. (Human vision sensitivity is close to a normal distribution over the 500-600nm spectrum)
  • Photosythetic Photon Flux -Â measuring the micromols of PAR per unit of time (Âµmol/s) (most similar to Lumens)
  • Photosynthetic Photon Flux Density (PPFD) - measuring the micromols of PAR in a given surface area per unit of timeÂ (Âµmol/m^2/s) (most similar to lux which is lumens per area). This is a measurement of how much light is actually reaching the plants (and available for photosynthesis).

Even PPFD is not a perfect measurement because plants sensitivity to light varies over the spectrum and sometimes even falls outside the normal PAR range. For example, UV emission (<400nm) had been shown to play a vital role in everything from THC content in cannabis to phytochemical content in basil.

So remember how I said that brightness has been oversimplified in the public domain? This is the challenge when trying to source cheaper, consumer targeted grow lights. Most consumer level grow lights are specified in Watts or Lumens, which as we know do not accurately specify the parameters we care about.

Therefore we need a way to approximate PPFD from the specs that are given, such as Watts or Lumens. While this will be very inaccurate, it is the best we have when the specs are not available. The steps to do this are

  1. Convert Watts to Lumens
    1. In the worst case scenario you can use average Lumens/Watt for the given light technology (hallide/sodium/LED). Lumens/Watt is also a general measure of light efficiency (light output / total energy input)
  2. Convert Lumens to PPF (Approximation)
    1. Lumens is a unit based on the human eye's sensitivity to light, which is a distribution of a limited spectrum of light. Converting a spectral power distribution (SPD) to lumens is a lossy process. We really need the SPD to calculate an accurate PPF.
    2. Therefore, we need to approximate the SPD of the original light source and use lumens to back calculate PPF. There are online calculators that can do this.
  3. Determine PPFD based on distance and light optical characteristics (lens/reflector)
    1. This is where we actually design something

Â 

Designing for PPFD

Based on CEA science, we know that plants need anywhere from 200-1000 PPFD based on the maturity of the plant and the concentration of carbon dioxide. There are a few ways to go about finding or designing grow lights to meet these demands.

The first is to buy a grow light, which can be absurdly expensive ($1000+). Professional grow lights will provide spectral power distribution, PPF, light uniformity charts, and even PPFD charts for given light distances. This makes our job easy.

The second option is to build your own grow light where you will need to consider choices for light technology, lenses/reflectors, physical spacing, and heat dissipation. The aim is to provide uniform light which can be accomplished by lens/reflector design/choice or by using more sources of light (many small lights vs one big light).

uFarm is an indoor grow system with limited vertical space. LEDs or full spectrum flourescents are the best options because they are compact and they limit the amount of infrared radiation. LEDs are generally more efficient because the wavelength can be more finely tailored to the plants requirements and growth stage.

After designing my own grow lights I can confidently say that it is probably best to invest in a good grow light (unless you are great at making PCBs and plan to open-source the design).

Power/Signal Distribution

Below is the simplified circuit diagram for the prototype.

There are four main parameters that determine component needs.

  • Power type (AC vs DC)
  • Voltage (120V, 12V, 5V)
  • Power requirements (Wire ampacity)
  • Data Signal requirements (single wire vs multiwire, bandwidth and interference)

Actuated components have a range of power needs including 120VAC, 12VDC, and 5VDC. The micro-controller uses both I2C and simple GPIO high/low switching for actuation and control.Â 

It can be seen that the microcontroller uses multi-channel relays (solenoid switches) to control both AC components like the sump and DC components like the fans and valves. This allows the tiny microcontroller to switch large amounts of power/current at higher voltages.

Component Stack

I am too lazy to make a diagram so here is a bunch of words.

  • RobotDyn AC Dimmer
    • This component allows us to dim AC lights using Pulse Skip Modulation. It is essentially a logic level (3.3V) solid state relay (no solenoid) with built-in zero-cross detection (detect when voltage is 0). This allows an external microcontroller to switch the light on/off at the right time, either skipping an entire sine wave or only transferring partial sine waves. Transferring partial sine waves requires consistent interrupts at the millisecond level (60Hz full sine wave, 1/120s for half wave) and consistent GPIO timing on the microsecond level (~32us for 8bit non-linear brightness control) which can be difficult or impossible with cheap microcontrollers. Skipping entire sine waves is easier, but can result in visibly flickering lights.
  • ATMEGA328
    • A small microcontroller that is used most famously by the Arduino Uno. It is used here to control the RobotDyn AC dimmers. It receives commands from the ESP32 over I2C.
  • ESP32
    • A wifi connected microcontroller that is great for DIY IOT and smart home projects.Â  It receives, interprets, and executes MQTT commands from higher level control software
  • Server/Raspberry Pi
    • This is the main brain for the system. It runs all of the software for the user interface and control logic.

Software

Again, too lazy to make a diagram (sorry). Let's review the general software architecture.

  • Embedded
    • This is micro-contoller specific compiled C code that runs on the ESP32 and the ATMEGA328
  • Server
    • Any sort of VM/container setup works here. I use a combination of Proxmox, Unraid, Ubuntu, and Docker to manage the physical hardware.
  • Frontend
    • HomeAssistant is a great fit for high level control and remote access of the system. It can also be used to create automations.
    • NodeRed makes complex automation easier with visual flow programming.
  • Backend
    • Eclipse MQTT Server runs to enable communication between the Server and Embedded ControllerÂ 
    • Letsencrypt/NGINX creates a secure reverse proxy to access the HomeAssistant instance anywhere in the world
    • DDNS is setup through Cloudflare to deal with residential ephemeral IP addresses

Â 

Future Updates

I hope to update some sections with more detailed information including

  • design and component details
  • tradeoffs
  • alternatives

But don't hold your breath. Feel free to contact me with specific questions!

entry.summary: Why Simulate?Communication is one of the most important opportunities for self driving cars. If you do not agree, I wrote…
entry.content:
Why Simulate?

Communication is one of the most important opportunities for self driving cars. If you do not agree, I wrote an article just for you. However, communication is often overlooked due to a variety of implementation challenges.

One such challenge is a lack of a clear value proposition that motivates widespread adoption. Because widespread adoption of V2X technology is expensive, the best way to test value propositions is through traffic simulation.

However, simulating connected and autonomous vehicles is still on the cutting edge of simulation technology and practices. Many connected and automated vehicle simulations exist within custom-built simulation frameworks for academic papers. These simulation frameworks are not easily adaptable by traffic engineers or urban planners.

This is why I created a generalized Python software package that makes it easier to simulate connected and automated vehicle use cases in the leading traffic simulation software, PTV Vissim.

If you want some immediate audio-visual satisfaction, you can check out my technical presentation at the 2019 Transportation Research Board Visualization Symposium in Washington, DC.

Disclaimer: You may be confused to see UAVs in a ground traffic simulator. To learn more about the research objectives behind this presentation, read my article on Cooperative Autonomy. (coming late September)

Simulation Scope

From simulating the chassis dynamics of a single vehicle to simulating the traffic dynamics of an entire city, there is a wide range of simulation purposes and tools. Many autonomous vehicle companies are building custom video game style simulators complete with soft sensors (simulated LiDAR/RaDAR/Cameras) and proprietary 3D point clouds of entire cities. These simulations are focused on improving the perception and decision making abilities of self driving cars.

Communication inherently involves two or more vehicles therefore the scope is naturally larger, on the scope of tens to hundreds of vehicles. This scale comfortably falls into the traditional range of microscopic traffic simulation where PTV Vissim and Eclipse SUMO. SUMO is often used in academic publications while PTV Vissim is often used by traffic professionals at the state and national levels.

PTV Vissim

Vissim does not have any built-in V2X capabilities, however it does have an API/COM interface which can be used to programatically control simulation parameters. This means that external V2X capabilities can be built and integrated into existing Vissim simulations. If you watch the presentation above you will see that V2X capabilities were added to the Karlsruhe traffic simulation that is provided by Vissim as a training example.

Python API

Here is an overview of how the external V2X Python library integrates with Vissim. It is important to note that simulations can be controlled from the Vissim interface or directly from the Python interpreter.

Features

  • Add V2X to existing simulations, including simulations that already use a Python script, with a few lines of code
  • Messages are realistically broadcasted/relayed (drop/loss and delay due to distance and congestion)
  • Define all custom message handling logic in a single project file
  • Allows for co-simulation and external visualization
  • Standardized platooning, dynamic speed harmonization, and collision avoidance routines make common use cases faster to build (not yet added)

Limitations

  • Simulation time step. Microscopic traffic is often simulated at 10 steps per second, or 0.1 second time intervals. This means that dynamic events like automated emergency braking are not suitable for microscopic traffic simulation.
  • Speed. Externally control simulations (simulations started from the Python interpreter) have severe speed limitations. This is a result of how Vissim has engineered its COM interface.

entry.content:
Houston, we have a problem

Ants, bees, and humans. All three of these animals form highly collaborative networks that allow them to improve the efficiency of food foraging or reprimand a foolish driver ðŸ¤¬. In fact, almost every example of complex networks in nature rely on this one thing that self-driving cars can not do...

Communicate.Â 

If you are from the transport industry or work on autonomous vehicles you may be rolling your eyes at the moment ðŸ™„. Communication in transportation has been on the development board for a LONG time. The U.S. government reserved spectrum in the 5.9GHz frequency range for vehicular use back in 1999 (FCC 99-305)!!! Even with developed standards like IEEE 802.11p and SAE J2735 and a proposed mandate of DSRC radios from USDOT in 2016, vehicle to anything (V2X) communication has failed to make a significant impact in transportation for reasons beyond the scope of this article.

However, in the last ten years machine learning and improved computing power has led to huge leaps in autonomous vehicle development. According to some estimates, more than eighty billion dollars has been dedicated to the pursuit of self driving cars. With so much to loose and even more to gain, the autonomous vehicle industry is highly competitive and resources are carefully allocated. V2X is nowhere near the top of the priority list, but it should be.

In nature and in aviation, communication is a defining safety and optimization technology. V2X is poised to improve autonomous vehicle safety, but serious challenges exist.

This opinion piece will further explore why communication is important and what challenges stand in the way of progress.

Why communication is important.

Bio-mimicry has been one of the most interesting areas of scientific study and engineering design in the past decade. In machine learning, neural networks are based on the understanding of how human brains work and have led to immense gains in the practicality and use of machine learning techniques. Without neural networks, self-driving cars as we know them today would not exist.

Bio-mimicry has also made its way into other engineering domains such as control systems and traffic management. Researchers have studied everything from bee foraging methods to ant colony traffic to design autonomous intersection management and cooperative cruise control (platoon) algorithms. These algorithms fundamentally rely on inter-vehicle communication. This is less sci-fi fantasy and more of an everyday occurrence than you might think.

Four-way stops? Pedestrian crossings? The reality is that we use more than just our brake lights and indicators to signal our intent. Autonomous vehicle companies have recognized this for a long time and modified vehicle controls to more closely mimic human driving behaviors. However, this method of communication or "language" is neither standardized nor inherently safe.

Ask the U.S. Federal Aviation Agency or any other international aviation agency about the importance of clear and precise communication. Even in the wide open space above our heads, communication (ADS-B and voice) is necessary to ensure safety.

In other words, aviation industry investments in communication have led to measurable safety improvements.

There is a plethora of evidence from both nature and other transportation industries that communication is a key component to safety and optimization. However, communication has yet to find its place in ground transportation.

Challenges

As mentioned in the introduction, there has been little progress in ground transportation communication given the 20+ year history of the industry. The current state of the U.S. industry is raveled in indecision. If we want to unlock the full potential of communication for ground transportation we need to tackle some big challenges.

When ITS and DSRC concepts were developed in the 1990's and 2000's, autonomous vehicles were a gutter dream. Cars were human driven AND owned. While DSRC could have improved overall public safety, there was little market incentive for vehicle manufacturers to justify R&D costs. The government stepped in (as it should have) to fund research, technology, and standards. Even with government support, market incentive did not develop.

Fast-forward to 2020 and autonomous vehicles completely change the paradigm.

  1. AVs rely on data from sensors
    1. AVs rely on a multitude of sensors that are error-prone in certain circumstances. LiDARs do not like snow and rain, cameras hate glare from direct sunlight. Each sensor has a failure mode, so a range of sensor types helps to reduce the number of complete failure modes. Communication offers information rich data that can supplement existing sensors (blind corners, vehicles trajectories, etc).
  2. AVs are expected to be company owned/operated
    1. Safety will no longer be sold on a sticker (see NCAP), so AV developers and transportation providers will be required to maintain incredibly high safety standards. There is clear economic motivation to invest in technology that measurably improves safety (rather than measures of safety that sell cars).

So why are AV companies not devoting resources to communication efforts?Â 

Egg or Chicken

Language is only useful if other people understand it. So how do you start a language? Similarly, a two-sided market like Uber is only useful if there are both drivers and riders. Two-sided markets rely on network effects, which are now a core principle in many digital businesses. While there may be a company using network effects to build an "Airbnb for pets", no one has fully solved the two-sided market style challenges for V2X.

However, a crack is developing. Telematics is already an important/standard part of autonomous vehicles system for monitoring and dispatch. Cellular V2X standards are in the process of being developed that would make V2X integration a negligible cost. The question is, how do you bring the other side of the market to the table? Human driven cars are not disappearing anytime too soon. Cities are becoming more pedestrian centric. Road work will continue to be an entire season in Michigan.Â 

Security

As with any cyber-physical system, malicious hacking could cause serious physical destruction. The good news is that communication security is a long studied field with great tools and processes; thank you world wide internet! The bad news is that there are still security challenges for decentralized, wireless, real-time communication networks.

There may always be some vulnerability that we are willing to accept; e.g. interfering with GPS systems it relatively easy, but doing so will land you in federal prison for a long time. In any case, success of ground transport communication is inherently linked with improvements in security.

Technology

There is currently a silent battle taking place between DSRC (ITS-G5/IEEE 802.11p) and C-V2X (3GPP). DSRC is the incumbent technology that has been backed by government for more than a decade. C-V2X is a relatively new addition created by the mobile communication industry. C-V2X defines new/different physical and medium access control (MAC) layers. Qualcomm, a major manufacturer of wireless chips, describes C-V2X as having "increased communication range (~2X), better non-line-of-sight (NLOS) performance, enhanced reliability, and cost efficiency" when compared to DSRC. However, it is not that simple. A recent paper published in the 2019 IEEE VTC shows that C-V2X under-performs DSRC in high vehicular density (urban) environments. There are pros and cons for both standards and the industry seems to be leaning towards a hybrid system. The reality is that technology adoption may depend on which use-case/implementation gains traction first.

Â 

Finding the Opportunity

Thanks for making it to this point in the article. There is a lot of opportunity waiting to be unlocked by self driving cars and vehicle communication technologies. However, it is difficult to make concrete assessments of this opportunity without the proper tools.

Traffic simulation is a powerful tool that gives traffic engineers and urban planners a way to assess the potential impact of traffic pattern and infrastructure changes. However, there is no great way to simulate generalized connected vehicle use cases.

This is why I created a Python library for PTV Vissim, a leading traffic simulator, that makes it easier for researchers and engineers to simulate connected and automated vehicle use cases.

Learn more about simulating connected and autonomous vehicles in my next article.Â 

Simulating Autonomous Vehicles

entry.title: uFarm | Product
entry.summary: Growing your own food can be as simple as a plant in a glass of water. However, a glass of…
entry.content:
Growing your own food can be as simple as a plant in a glass of water. However, a glass of water did not solve my food growing problems. So, I designed and built an automated, apartment-sized, aquaponic grow system that I released as an open-source project on Github. For the motivation behind this project check out my article, Why Food Sucks.

This is the first article in a series about the uFarm product design process. The series will delve into three distinct areas of the design process;

  1. Product | Building a useful product that actually solves problems.
  2. Aquaponics | Plant science turned into design parameters. (Coming mid-September)
  3. Engineering | Iterative design of a cyber-physical system.

The series will end with;

  1. Outcomes | Running and testing the prototype. (coming mid-September)
  2. Build Log | Pictures and comments from the process. (coming mid-September)

Social Impact Disclaimer

uFarm is built with the intent for social impact. It attempts to solve real user problems/pains in a way that tackles systemic problems with the food system. In many ways it is a low cost experiment to assess the viability of a social startup.

The organic movement is a good example of what uFarm is trying to achieve. Without the work of film makers and non-profits, consumers would have no reason to choose organic produce at the shop or eat at a farm to table restaurant. While the organic movement has become overly commercialized, it has at least moved the public to be more conscious of what they eat.

Table of Contents

  • Social Impact Disclaimer
  • Product
    • Problems
    • Users
    • Business Environment
      • Competition
      • Technology Trends
      • Regulatory
    • Product Specs
    • Trade-offs
      • Aquaponic vs Nutrient Dosing
      • Size
      • Automation
      • Customizability vs Simplicity

Product

What problems does uFarm solve? Who is it for? How is it strategically positioned? What features should be built first? These are all part of the product vision that inform engineering design choices. While uFarm is an experimental side project that is not meant to be commercialized, it is meant to have value. Product and user focused thinking helped me to test more valuable hypotheses with the initial uFarm prototype.

Problems

Taking startup methods cues from Steve Blank and Eric Ries, uFarm is based on a number of hypotheses about the problem, user, and solution. In my opinion, startups in the personal food growing space often fail because they do not identify painful problems. Rather, they create new problems including maintenance and living space clutter. uFarm is focused on common problems that are shared by anyone who cooks food at home.

  1. Food spoilage
    1. A surprising amount of food waste occurs because food portions sold at groceries are too large or because you didn't get around to making that basil pesto as soon as you had hoped. This is especially true for people that do not live with a partner or family.
  2. Time
    1. It is taco night, how often have you forgotten the cilantro/corriander and had to take a quick run to the shop. Or, more realistically, you have taco supplies at home and there is no way that you are venturing outside of your house to buy fresh produce.
  3. Cannot purchase at grocer
    1. For culinary enthusiasts it can be hard to find ethnic or regional varieties of herbs. Kaffir lime, curry leaves, holy/thai basil, birdseye chilis, and even lemongrass can be hard to find. Because these herbs are less popular they sit on shelves for longer periods and quickly loose their flavor and/or spoil before they make it into your mouth.
  4. Sustainability and production transparency
    1. What you choose to eat has a large impact on the environment and people's lives. At the end of the day, certifications and labels like USDA Organic or Free-Trade Certified are ultimately stacks of paperwork that the consumer can neither view nor verify.

At a societal level there are additional problems. A quick overview of these problems were given from a system perspective in my article, Why Food Sucks. However, I want to reframe these problems with a user perspective.

  • Cooking is hard
    • Not everyone is a Ferran Adria or a Nathan Myhrvold. Many American families no longer pass down a plethora of family recipes for daily consumption. There are too many "influencer chefs" that give garbage recipes and poor cooking techniques. Deciding on what to cook and knowing how to cook it is too large of a barrier for many, especially if what you cook tastes no better than your local Chipotle.
    • It takes a lot of time to go and buy fresh ingredients, especially if you live in a food desert.
    • It takes even more time to plan meals so that food does not spoil in your fridge.

Â 

  • You are good at tasting for sugar, not nutrition
    • That delicious apple at your local grocer was probably in storage for eight or more months. During that time it lost most of its nutritional value and is now just a convenient ball of sugar water. But hey it still tastes good right?
    • That pint of cherry tomatoes you just got, yeah it was picked before it was ripe and then artificially ripened with ethylene gas during transportation. It doesn't have the same nutritional value as tomatoes allowed to naturally ripen on the plant.
    • John Hopkins on the marketing and labeling of food

Â 

  • No one taught me
    • Home economic classes have been killed off. Both parents have full time jobs. Food is bought in plastic containers. Potatoes grow on trees like tomatoes, right?
    • How we eat is heavily influenced by family, friends, and society.

Â 

  • Out of sight, out of mind
    • The rain forest is being destroyed so you can eat your donuts and potato chips made with palm oil (often just listed as vegetable oil).
    • Cattle farming. So many problems here from more deforestation to animal abuse.
    • Human abuse. You really don't want to know how your tea and coffee is produced. It is quite ironic that American companies now support behavior which the Country fought against for independence, [cough] Boston Tea Party.

Wow. Those are a lot of problems. Hopefully the next sections are easier reads.

Users

Passion for an idea can easily lead to feature creep and a lack of user focus. If the product is socially important then everyone should use it right? While widespread adoption may be the goal for the greatest social impact, product success does not grow on trees. Again taking cues from the tech startup world, Geoffrey Moore and his book Crossing the Chasm offer a commonly used framework to think about user categories and market adoption. This section will focus on

  1. Innovators
  2. Early Adopters

The ideal innovator is both a tech and plant geek. There aren't many of us. We have a broad understanding of electronics/computers and love to build rather than talk. Each of us are interesting in plants for different reasons. Some of us found a love for plants through food, some of us grew up working in gardens or on farms, and some just want to grow plants on spaceships for interstellar journeys. The innovator has an account on Github and uses it to try out projects that other people have created. The innovator is not worried about blowing a fuse or fixing a leak.

The early adopter is not as technically literate. However, what they lack in technical skill they make up for in passion for fixing our food system. They are careful about what food they buy and who they buy it from. They attend their local farmers market and they probably have a small garden at home. They may subscribe to food philosophies such as veganism, but they understand that these philosophies are about principles and not about rules. They are looking to do more, but time is a limiting factor.

Business Environment

Competition

uFarm is not the first automated home grow system. Grove Ecosystem is a failed startup that raised over $4M USD from high profiles investors like Tim Ferris in 2016. Grove struggled with manufacturing and seemed to fail at attracting early adopters. There are many smaller countertop aquaponic systems like EcoGarden and Aquasprouts, however these are extremely small and simple solutions that are more of a display piece than a useful tool. There are also automated grow boxes that rely on nutrient dosing such as Grobo, Seedo, and Leaf. Most of the automated hydroponic systems focus on growing cannabis, which seems to be one of the only profitable target markets at the moment.

There are very few open-source hydroponic projects. The most famous project is the publicly criticized and recently closed OpenAg project at MIT which created the Personal Food Computer.Â 

There are also projects aimed at automating traditional soil culture such as Farmbot, a personal favorite.Â 

Â 

People can also grow food in their backyard or on their windowsill, although many urban dwellers do not have either of those options. The figure below shows the options for growing food at home.

For a more detailed comparison of solutions for home growing take a look at the Blue Ocean style figure below.

Technology Trends

uFarm relies on the success and further development of a few core technologies.

  • Light Emitting Diodes | Hail Haitz
  • Sensors (pH, EC, DO, lux, etc) | Cost, robustness
  • Cameras | Cost, wavelength
  • Processors | Moore please
  • Web Tech | edge-computing and user interface capabilities
  • Machine Learning | tools to automatically assess plant health problems

Regulatory

The regulatory environment is non-prohibitive and there are a number of legislative opportunities that would be extremely beneficial including;

  • Environmental Protection, Carbon Tax
  • Supply Chain Transparency
  • Agricultural Chemical Use Restrictions
  • Redistribution of agricultural subsidies to better support small/local farmers

(more detail to be added)

Product Specs

While these aren't detailed product specs that would be used for Jira/Confluence, the following should give a good idea of how product design is prioritized. These product specs are for an MVP targeting innovators and do not represent the specs for the original prototype.

  1. Hardware
    1. Footprint less than 10 ft2 or 1 m2
    2. Autonomous for a minimum of 1 month.
    3. Bimonthly maintenance/cleaning.
    4. Ability to grow any leafy green (vegetative growth)
    5. Production rate of 3 kilograms per month
    6. Off the shelf components, locally source-able
    7. Build time of 12 hours
    8. Limit tools to drill, saw, knife, wire stripper, and soldering pencil.
  2. Software
    1. Use existing open-source projects
    2. Extensible
      1. Easily customize automation
      2. Integrate with smart home
      3. Community grow recipes
    3. Remote Management
    4. One click install

Trade-offs

At a system level, there are a number of major decisions to make, each with their own (and sometimes coupled) trade-offs.

Aquaponic vs Nutrient Dosing

Pros Cons
  • Aquaponics is inherently more stable (pH, nutrients), reducing the chance of plant death
  • Nutrient dosing allows for greater control over growing conditions, including flowering/fruit growth
  • Aquaponics relies on establishing a bacterial colony
  • Nutrient dosing is costly to automate and is sensitive to sensor drift which increases maintenance requirements

Size

Larger Smaller
  • Grow more food
  • Less sensitive to wide swings in growing conditions
  • More customization and expandable
  • Takes up less space
  • Smaller initial investment
  • Less setup time

Automation

More Less
  • Reduce maintenance
  • Measure and optimize growing
  • Cheaper
  • Simpler, smaller number of components that could fail

Customizability vs Simplicity

With any product there is an inherent trade-off between customizability and simplicity. Android vs Apple, API vs web interface, blank notebook vs planner, etc. The clear initial design directive here is modularity. As seen in the sections above, there are clear engineering trade-offs for size and automation. Designing with these modularity parameters in mind can allow the product to shift in response to user demands.

Next in this series is Aquaponics | Plant science turned into design parameters (Coming mid-September) where we delve into the biology, chemistry, physics, and other physical science phenomena that make uFarm work.

Read Part 2

entry.title: How to Never Kill Another Plant
entry.summary: Over-watering is the #1 cause of houseplant death. What if I told you there was a way to never worry…
entry.content:
Over-watering is the #1 cause of houseplant death.

What if I told you there was a way to never worry about watering your plants again, even when absent for months at a time. What if I told you there is a way to grow plants twice as fast with no synthetic fertilizer? This article will discuss how create a self-sustaining indoor grow system that requires very little maintenance and can provide a surprisingly large amount of food.

In the previous two articles Why Food Sucks and The Future of Food is Hyper-local, I reviewed critical issues with our current food system and potential solutions to those issues. Growing your own food is a small, but important piece of the solution to building a healthier, more sustainable food system. Using the scientific understanding of hydroponics and engineering principles from system design and automation, growing your own food can be a realistic goal even for time-constrained urban dwellers. This is the idea behind the uFarm open-source project. Learn more about how I designed uFarm.

uFarm

uFarm uses principles from aquaponics to design a self-sustaining micro-ecosystem that can grow plants for weeks to months without any intervention or maintenance.

I left the system running autonomously for more than a month while travelling and I came back to plants that had quadrupled in size.

Aquaponics is a way of providing nutrients to plants that mimics a natural ecosystem cycle.

  1. Fish are fed (possibly with food scraps)
  2. Fish produce waste (ammonia)
  3. Nitrifying bacteria convert ammonia to nitrites and then nitrates
  4. Plants uptake nitrates, in effect cleaning the water for the fish

A variety of hydroponic techniques can be applied to aquaponics. The initial uFarm prototype uses flood & drain media beds as well as deep water culture, however nutrient film technique or aeroponics can also be designed into an aquaponic system.

How uFarm Works

uFarm is not just a simple aquaponic system, it is a highly automated, connected, and integrated system. It was designed using a variety of engineering tools from Darcy-Weisbach fluid flow equations to multi-physics modelling for over-constrained mechanical loading conditions. The entire system is highly coupled, which is engineering speak that means if you change the size/design/specification of one component then it changes multiple other system component requirements. For simplicity, much of the high-level parametric design was carried out in a spreadsheet that could be used to design systems that are larger or smaller. Don't worry, I am not going into technical detail in this article. However, if you want to dive into the design and engineering process then head to my article on Designing uFarm.

Â The idea behind uFarm is to hide a lot of the difficult engineering and biology behind easy to use design tools and user interfaces.

To get a better sense of what goes into a uFarm system take a look at the system diagram below. This system is fully recirculating and contains enough water to run for more than a month (accounting for evaporation and plant uptake). In fact, this system requires less maintenance than a normal fish tank because the plants are doing the heavy lifting of removing excess nitrates from the system.

  1. Water is first pumped to the top fish tank from the bottom DWC containers. The pump is controlled by the system's computer which regulates the watering cycles.
  2. Water from the fish tank then overflows into the media beds in the middle. The media beds serve a variety of purposes. It traps physical fish waste particles and also houses the majority of the nitrifying bacteria that breaks down ammonia into nitrates.
  3. The media beds are designed as a flood and drain system. Each bed has an electronically activated direct action valve and water sensor that controls when the water from the bed is drained into the DWC container below.

The Growing Edge of Plant Research

NASA has been a leader in hydroponic science (it's the best way to grow food in space thanks to its recirculating design). While there is a good amount of fundamental science that understands how "root zone" conditions affect plant growth, there are still a huge number of growth parameter questions. Each plant has it's own specific environmental condition "recipes" that optimize growth and specific chemical compound concentrations that affect flavor and more.

Nutrient concentrations, pH, dissolved oxygen, temperature, light spectral power distributions, humidity, CO2 concentrations are all parameters that affect plant growth. These parameters vary over time and influence plant growth. For example, many fruiting plants require shorter light cycles with more red light to enter a flowering/fruiting stage.

If you enter the Google Scholar hydroponics rabbit hole (like I did) you will find journal articles that study specific growth parameters for specific species of plants. There is no unified theory that can fully optimize growth for any plant. As a science nerd, this really gets me going. I get to play with knowledge at the edge of scientific understanding... and I get to eat the results afterwards!

uFarm is built with this experimentation in mind. The system is capable of programmatically changing growing parameters such as light intensity, light spectral distribution, water cycles, humidity, and temperature. In other words, it can follow tried and tested grow recipes or it help you experiment and create your own.

How to Design Your Own uFarm

uFarm is more than just a single design as seen in pictures above. It aims to be a set of open-source design tools and software infrastructure that can help anyone create an automated hydroponic/aquaponic system that fits their specific needs (size, cost, types of plants).

Unfortunately that goal is still a few years in the future. In the short-term, the project aims to offer more "base-models" or specific size configurations that will fit most users' needs. If you are technically included (hardware or software) then head over to the uFarm Github page and give it a follow. If you are interested in checking out the build log for the prototype system then check out my article on Designing uFarm.

Overall, the system worked amazingly well for a prototype. It kept me fed with seriously good tasting herbs and required almost zero effort/time. However, there was a lot of learning from the initial prototype.

  1. Building a custom glass fish tank was stupid hard for an inexperienced caulker. In my opinion, the aesthetic improvement was not worth the effort.
  2. The piping design needs to be modified to reduce noise. Gurgling water is quite loud in a small apartment.
  3. The system was too large for a single person. I was making basil pesto so often that I had to give it away to friends.
  4. Media beds were too time intensive to build and tear down. Would probably design a NFT/Drip Irrigation level with a separate bio and particle filter.
  5. DWC bed was difficult to keep light tight. Light exposure causes excess algae growth which increases maintenance. This will also be an issue for aeroponics and NFT systems.
  6. The intensity and color of the light can be disruptive to a living area. Automated or adjustable shrouds would be a great addition.

Â

entry.title: The Future of Food is Hyper-local
entry.summary: The image below is the first result on Google for the search term "agriculture". It is also what first comes…
entry.content:
The image below is the first result on Google for the search term "agriculture". It is also what first comes to mind for most people. However, traditional soil culture methods alone do not meet the needs of a growing world population and growing urban centers. Incremental improvement and corporate mergers are not sustainable solutions for the future of our food.

If you haven't already read my article, Why Food Sucks, this would be a great time. This is the second article in a three part series on automated urban farming. As mentioned in the previous article, a possible "radical" solution to our growing food problems is to rewind the clock and return to a more decentralized production model using the latest scientific understanding of topics from the biology of plants to the quantum physics of LEDs.

Hyper-local food production is such a vision for the future. In fact, you may already be purchasing food from one of the many hyper-local farms including Bowery, Green City Growers, BrightFarms, Great Lakes Growers, Plenty, and Aerofarms.

Hyper-local Food Production

Hyper-local food production at commercial scales generally aims to solve two main problems posed in Why Food Sucks;

  1. Transportation
  2. Chemical and pharmaceutical use

Removing these problems from the equation enables;

  1. Cultivars chosen for flavor/nutrition
  2. Food harvested closer to peak flavor/nutrition
  3. Reduced emissions from transportation
  4. Reduced number of middle men (more supply chain transparency, less corruption)
  5. Reduced ecological damage from pesticides (save the bees!)
  6. Reduce possible chronic disease caused by chemical use
  7. More "in-tune" and responsive to community needs/wants

This is ironic to me because, in this narrow perspective, food production was better a century ago than it is now.

So what does hyper-local food production actually look like anyway?Â 

Hyper-local food production can range from personal gardens to large indoor vertical farms.

The more decentralized and diverse food production is the more resistant it is to any single source of failure (disease, drought, destruction, etc). It is important to have a range of production scales.

Commercial Scale

There are a lot of people that need to eat. Modern controlled environment agriculture (CEA) science allows us to grow produce more quickly, in higher densities, with better water efficiency than ever before. Hydroponics is a fast developing field of agricultural science that is at the heart of the commercial scale operations seen above. The most popular hydroponic techniques used at a commercial scale are

  • Vertical and Roof Farms
    • Aeroponics
    • Nutrient Film Technique (NFT) a.k.a. Shallow Water Culture (SWC)
  • Greenhouses
    • Deep Water Culture (DWC)
    • Substrate-based
      • Ebb and Flow a.k.a. Flood and Drain
      • Drip Irrigation

Hydroponics is generally defined in the United States as growing plants without soil (including non-soil substrates like rockwool). This means that macro and micro nutrients that normally come from the soil or fertilizers must be provided through other means. Many hydroponic operations use nutrient dosing (adding refined macro/micro nutrient concentrates) to easily create the proper conditions for optimal growth.

However there are more natural ways to grow produce hydroponically. One such method is called aquaponics.

Aquaponics is a hydroponic growing method where fish and plants are grown symbiotically, mimicking the nitrogen cycle in nature.

Fish produce waste which are converted to nitrates by bacteria. The plants then clean the water for the fish by uptaking nitrates and other macro/micro nutrients. You can read more about aquaponics in the next article.

Community Scale

Humans have been foraging and cultivating food forever. Finding food, growing food, and harvesting food all have deeply ingrained reward mechanisms that evolved over tens of thousands of years. Communities that grew food together survived together. It would be biologically ignorant to disregard the social benefits of community gardens.Â 

Community gardens also help educate people about food. What does good/fresh food actually taste like? What varieties exist? How do you cook it? These are important questions that can encourage commercial scale operations to produce a wider variety of produce, which ultimately provides a more comprehensive source of nutrition. While community gardens can be difficult for a working community to manage and upkeep, there are design methodologies that could help, such as permaculture. Permaculture is a fascinating area of biomimetic agricultural design to dive into if sustainability and ecology interest you.

Ultimately, community gardens need to start from within the community and personal gardens are a great way to start.

Personal Scale

Growing food at home has many of the same benefits as community gardens. Growing food at home is not about reducing food costs. It is about flavor, variety, a sense of accomplishment, and a connection with nature. However, growing food at home can be difficult for busy families and urban dwellers, especially at a scale that provides more than a handful of tomatoes or a single annual bushel of basil.

Luckily, there are a few options to reduce the burden of managing a home garden (micro-farm). For traditional outdoor or greenhouse soil-culture there is the open-source Farmbot (I am a huge fan), which automatically seeds, waters, and weeds an outdoor grow bed. There are also hydroponic systems that are designed for indoor use such as Seedo and Grobo. Unsurprisingly, these startups are focused on the cannabis market and should also work well for other fruiting plants like tomato and pepper. However, they are not great designs for serious leafy green and herb production.

As a cooking/food enthusiast and also a busy urban dweller, I sought a solution that would allow me to grow enough produce for daily meals..... inside my 700 sqft third-floor apartment.

This is what led me to design and build uFarm, an automated nano-farm for urban dwellers.Â  If you are immediately interested in the technical details and build process then feel free to skip to my article on Designing uFarm. Otherwise, the third article in this series will discuss the Why and What of uFarm. Continue reading to see how easy it is to grow your own food!

Part 3
