entry.title: The Ultimate Fulbright Guide
entry.summary: There is a lot to know and an overwhelming amount of information on the web about Fulbright. This post will…
entry.content:
There is a lot to know and an overwhelming amount of information on the web about Fulbright. This post will serve as a hub with what I think (my personal opinions) are the best sources of information for prospective applicants looking to complete a Fulbright abroad.

Table of Contents

  • Where to Start?
  • What is Fulbright?
  • Benefits of Being a Fulbright Scholar
    • How I Benefited from Fulbright (United Kingdom)
      • Tangibles
      • Intangibles
      • London
      • Additional Opportunities
  • Is Fulbright worth it?
  • How do I select an Award to apply for?
  • How do I apply?
  • Chances of getting a Fulbright scholarship?
  • What makes a competitive application?
    • Audience
    • Advice from the UK Commission
  • How do I improve my application?
  • Other Questions

Where to Start?

  1. The best place to start is the official Fulbright website. I highly recommend reading through all of the "About" sections. Most questions can be answered there. The Eligibility page is also an important read (spoiler: you can't yet have a doctorate degree but you must have a bachelor degree by the start of the grant period)
  2. If you are currently a student or are recently graduated the next best place to start is with your university's Fulbright Program Advisor (FPA). The FPA is often a faculty member dedicated to helping students with the application process. Do not discount their experience and knowledge about the general process! You can use the Fulbright website to search for your university's FPA. They will probably appreciate it if you read the info on the official website first ðŸ˜
  3. Read the rest of this post.
  4. Check out current and past Fulbright Alumni Ambassadors and reach out! Alternatively, find the person who had the Award you are interested (Linkedin and Google are good starting points, or use the Fulbright Grantee Directory)
  5. Check out Recorded Webinars with detailed application information.

What is Fulbright?

Since you already know the basics I am going to delve into some of the complexities of the program to provide better context.Â 

  • The Fulbright umbrella actually contains multiple academic-based programs
    • the Fulbright U.S. Student Program, for students and professionals
    • the Fulbright Scholar Program, for university faculty
    • other specific awards, see the full list on the State Department website
  • The Fulbright Programs are partially funded by annual appropriations from Congress and are housed under the Department of State, specifically the Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs (ECA). However, ECA contracts the administration of the program to The Institute of International Education. Other funding (less than 50% as of 2019) comes from partner countries and institutions. However some Fulbright Awards are fully financed by partner countries or institutions.
    • This means that the program is funded at the discretion of Congress and under the policy direction of the Executive Branch. The President appoints the J. William Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board (FFSB).
      • Fulbright has long received bipartisan support from Congress because the program has a concrete impact in both developing leaders and increasing "soft power" worldwide. It is seen as one of the most powerful peace keeping tools and is strongly supported by military generals.
    • Awards come and go as foreign affairs policy and relationships change (both in the U.S. and in partner countries). The availability of an Award may also be dependent on a specific institution.
  • Fulbright is a partnership program between the U.S. and 160+ countries. While IIE administers the project in the U.S., they rely on working with partner countries for both funding, implementation, and applications of the Fulbright programs.
    • Many of the largest partner countries (49) have commissions which oversee the program. A full list is here. While U.S. embassies oversee the program directly in many other countries.
    • This means that a foreign commission or a U.S. embassy will most likely make the final decision on your application.

ECA also houses other international exchange programs so be sure to check them out!!!

Benefits of Being a Fulbright Scholar

The website gives the tangible benefits of the Award which includes at minimum

  • round-trip transportation to the host country
    • A lump sum for you to book your own transportation
  • funding to cover room, board, and incidental costs
    • How generous this is depends on a variety of factors including cost of living. The expectation is to be funded at the level of an American graduate student (GRA/GTA), however some Awards provide more (or possibly less).
  • Federal government non-competitive eligibility (NCE) status for 12 months
    • great if you want to work at a federal agency (NASA/DOE/CIA/etc) after Fulbright

However, if these were the only benefits then there would be very little difference from GTA/GRA funding. Fulbright is such a prized award because of the country specific and intangible benefits that cannot be guaranteed nor freely received. I will provide examples from my own experience and also link to other Fulbrighter's posts as I find them.

How I Benefited from Fulbright (United Kingdom)

Tangibles

  • Full Tuition Waiver
  • Orientation in London | full itinerary
    • Q&A with U.S. Ambassador Barzun
    • Conversations with former Chief of Staff to Tony Blair
    • Houses of Parliament with Lord Victor Adebowale
  • Fulbright Forum in Newcastle | full itinerary
    • Visit Lord Mayorâ€™s Council Chambers,Â NewcastleÂ Civic CentreÂ 
    • Private viewing of Baltic Centre for Contemporary Art
    • Tour of Alnwick Gardens
  • End-cap in Edinburgh | full itinerary
  • Events at U.S. Embassy in London
  • RSA (Royal Society of Arts) Membership
    • Access to RSA House and exclusive events/lectures
  • Royal Oak Membership
  • Fulbrighter Access
    • Exclusive network for Fulbright Alumni

Intangibles

The most important yet the most difficult to explain with words and pictures. This is the real long term value of Fulbright.

  • friendships
  • network
  • self-development

London

London doesn't need an introduction. However, the new UCL School of Management campus in Canary Wharf, One Canada Square, has breathtaking views.

Additional Opportunities

Fulbright places you in a new environment and gives you credentials to make things happen. These are some of the highlights from my time in the UK to show what is possible.

  • Hacktrain 3.0 and Hong Kong
    • Participated in and won the largest transportation hackathon in Europe. Won trip to Hong Kong to participate in Hacktrain HK.
  • UCL Bright Ideas
    • entrepreneurial competition for equity-free grant sponsored by UCL
  • UCL Startup Trek - Tel Aviv
    • Led the School of Management trip to meet with the startup community in Israel
  • Founders of the Future, FFactor, Founder's Forum
    • Joined young entrepreneur organization and participated in UK's premier pitch competitionÂ 
  • Blockchain Live
    • Met with industry leaders when Bitcoin was at $30,000+ USD
  • HyperloopTT
    • Connected with founder of HyperloopTT and worked with them internationally
  • National and International Travel
    • Brighton, Bath, Cornwall, Kent, Newcastle, Manchester, Liverpool, Edinburgh, Scottish Highlands, France, Netherlands, Croatia

Is Fulbright worth it?

Yes. It obviously depends on what you make of it, but Fulbright is unrivaled for the breadth of opportunities available. For specific countries and universities there are comparable privately funded opportunities e.g. Rhodes and Schwarzman.

How do I select an Award to apply for?

The bad news. You can only apply for one Award. The good news. You only have to apply for one Award. There three main strategies you can use to select the right Award, but first some context.

In an ideal world you might have entered your undergraduate career with your eyes set on Fulbright and you have your career planned out at least 10 years. In this case it would be easy to chose an Award that best fits your needs. I don't know of many people who live in that ideal world.

I did not learn of Fulbright until my third year of undergrad. I also did not have a clear ten or five year plan. I was the first engineer in my family and I had just started to get involved in startups and research commercialization. However, I was focused on getting more international experience and Fulbright seemed like the ideal opportunity. Finding the right Fulbright Award was the first challenge. If you are in the position of getting ready to apply in the next application cycle then there are a few ways to narrow down your search.

  • Language
    • A number of countries have language requirements. Do you speak a language other than English? Could you become proficient in a language before applying? Generally less people apply to the Awards that have language requirements.
  • Restricted Awards
    • There are a number of Awards that are for a specific area of study or research. Because Awards change on a yearly basis, this takes a lot of due diligence to search through opportunities. Again, less people generally apply for restricted Awards.
  • Statistics
    • If you are interested in a general Award or an English Teaching Assistant then it may be useful to look at application statistics. Fulbright publishes limited application statistics that may help determine which Awards are highly competitive. Be cautious as application statistics vary every year and a low number of applications may encourage more people to apply the following year.
  • Your Dream
    • Always wanted to study in London? IT'S A TRAP! I repeat, IT'S A TRAP! This is not a good way to choose an Award because it is not fundamentally based in what makes a strong application. The U.S. Government and its taxpayers are not funding you to go have a year long vacation in your dream destination. They expect qualified candidates that are pursuing professional goals.

That being said, there are three main categories of Awards that you can apply for.

  • Study
    • Obtain a [post-]graduate degree. Often tied to a thesis/dissertation.
  • Research
    • Start or complete a research objective.
  • English Teaching Assistant
    • Teach English. Lots of opportunities all around the world.

Generally, the English Teaching Assistant Awards are the least competitive, but also have the largest selection of countries to choose from.

How do I apply?

The mechanics of the application process are all provided on the Fulbright website.Â  Definitely check out the application checklists and the application timeline. The only additional advice I can give here is to start EARLY (6+ months), which is much easier said than done.

  • Determine where your application may be weak and gain more experience before the application deadline.
  • Get an initial draft ASAP and revise over multiple months. Give time for your thoughts to coagulate and mature.

Chances of getting a Fulbright scholarship?

There is no good answer to this. From my experience, the Fulbright application review process is more comprehensive and well-rounded than any university application process. However, it is still a selection process and competition varies from year to year.

  • Fight the impostor syndrome. Looking at current Fulbright profiles can be daunting, but I can assure you that most successful Fulbright applicants feel the same way.
  • Making a decision solely on application statistics will probably lead to a weak application. Make sure to focus on your passions or goals and let that guide your application decisions.

What makes a competitive application?

There is a lot that goes into making a Fulbright Application. Your best course of action is to

  1. read the official Fulbright guidance
  2. reach out to a Fulbright alumni for more nuanced guidance

Otherwise here are some thoughts off the top of my head (avoid idioms in your application).

  • Write for your audience
    • see below
  • Follow good story telling techniques, e.g.
    • Hook
    • Information chunking
    • Story structure
    • Authenticity/Honesty
  • Big goals
  • Relevant experience
  • Passion for the mission of The Fulbright Program

Audience

Be sure to understand the stages of application review and the audience for which you are writing the application. Generally this includes;

  • Campus Committee
    • Unless you put little effort into your application and it would reflect poorly on the university, your committee should recommend your for the Award.
  • IIE/U.S. Selection
    • Applications are reviewed by relevant university faculty and professionals. You need to make sure you can convince this reader that your application is important/relevant and you are competent in your field of expertise.
  • Foreign Country
    • Foreign CommissionÂ 
      • Applications are generally reviewed by accomplished individuals who volunteer their time to review applications. Fulbright alumni may also read your applications. Your application should tell a story that does not overwhelm these readers with too much technical jargon. Be wary of assumptions that may come across as culturally ignorant.
    • Embassy
      • This section is incomplete and will be updated atÂ  future date.

Advice from the UK Commission

Link - We assess more than your academic record. The best applications are from well-rounded students who can demonstrate:

  • Ambassadorial skills
  • Intercultural sensitivityÂ 
  • Genuine desire to learn more about the UKÂ and to share aspects of American culture
  • ExtracurricularÂ activities
  • Community involvement
  • Leadership potential
  • Plans to further the Fulbright mission and giveÂ back to the US upon returning

How do I improve my application?

  • Get feedback from relevant faculty/professionals
  • Talk to a recent Fulbright alumnus (many are willing to help!)
  • Gain cultural insights from citizens of the foreign country
  • Gain more relevant academic/professional experience
  • Apply for relevant awards/competitions
  • Get some experience living abroad

Other Questions

  • Check out the Fulbright FAQ post with questions posed by real applicants.
  • Is this guide missing something? Please let me know! My contact info can be found on the Alumni Ambassador webpage.

entry.title: FAQ | United Kingdom Fulbright
entry.summary: As a Fulbright Alumni Ambassador, I often receive emails from prospective U.S. applicants with great questions about the Fulbright application…
entry.content:
As a Fulbright Alumni Ambassador, I often receive emails from prospective U.S. applicants with great questions about the Fulbright application and experience. This post includes real questions from real applicants. Keep in mind that many responses are geared towards a Study/Postgraduate Award in the U.K.. As mentioned in my Fulbright Guide, details about the Fulbright program vary from year to year and the opinions expressed here are my own. The ultimate source of accurate information is theÂ official Fulbright websiteÂ orÂ by contacting IIE directly.

Table of Contents

  • Frequently Asked Questions
    • Should I contact the program's director or admissions? Were they receptive/helpful?
    • Do you know who I would contact about country specific questions?
    • What were the most challenging or unexpected aspects of your Fulbright experience?
    • How did you craft a compelling Statement of Grant Purpose for a degree program without falling into traps such as repeating what was listed on the universityâ€™s website?
    • Did you explore any distinctions in your field between the U.S. and the U.K.? Why didÂ  you feel the U.K. was the right place for you to study?
    • How did you incorporate your international experience in your application?
    • Do I need a letter of affiliation? How do I get one?
    • One of my largest concerns is feeling like I am not good enough for the program and it is making writing my application difficult. What was your process for writing your application and what did you highlight that made you a stand out.Â 
    • Have you encountered any positives or negatives aboutÂ pursuing and receivingÂ a Master's degree abroad, as opposed to staying within the U.S.?Â 
    • Did you talk about specificÂ courses or professors that interested you within the program?Â 
    • Did you specify in your Statement of Grant Purpose yourÂ intended dissertation on public transportation, or was that something you developed while studying at UCL?
    • In what ways did London add or detract from your experience at UCL?Â 
    • For Host Country Engagement, did you focus on ways to get involved within the UCL campus or with London in general? In what ways did you end up engaging with the community?Â 
    • Any other tips or tricks?
    • General Thoughts

Frequently Asked Questions

Â 

Should I contact the program's director or admissions? Were they receptive/helpful?

I contacted the program director during the summer of my application. Letters of affiliation for degree programs were still suggested when I applied. They were very receptive and helpful and that can be expected from most faculty and programs that you would contact about the Fulbright. I had limited contact with the faculty compared to those who applied for research awards.

Do you know who I would contact about country specific questions?

First make sure to review the country specific information on the website, for example here is the country page for the UK. Next, check if the country has a Fulbright commission. Most commissions will have a website or some web presence. Again, for example here is the UK Commission website. Depending on your question you can also

  1. Contact IIE
  2. Contact the commisson/embassy, UK Commission contact info
  3. Find a Fulbright Alumni Ambassador or other alum from the relevant country

What were the most challenging or unexpected aspects of your Fulbright experience?

Everyone's unexpected challenges are quite different. Everything from severe sickness to housing problems. Living in London, most of my unexpected challenges had to do with housing.

How did you craft a compelling Statement of Grant Purpose for a degree program without falling into traps such as repeating what was listed on the universityâ€™s website?

The websiteÂ gives great info and lists the question at hand, "What are your reasons for selecting a particular institution?". To answer this question you should first speak to your current career trajectory/interests and then directly relate them to facts about the program you are applying to. For example, "I am studying the acute response of chimpanzees when they are shown pictures of cute golden retriever puppies. The program at France University has the most cute golden retriever puppies in the world and would further my research and professional development."

Did you explore any distinctions in your field between the U.S. and the U.K.? Why didÂ  you feel the U.K. was the right place for you to study?

For my application, cultural differences were not front in center when drawing contrast between the program I was applying for and everything else out there. I made my case around the specific structure/benefits of the degree program I was applying for, which was structured quite differently than other MBA degrees, and offered clear alignment with my goals.

How did you incorporate your international experience in your application?

Integrating your previous international experience is very important. If you feel that your international experience ties in nicely with your "pitch" in the SOGP then put it there. Put less ambiguously, if your international experience is related to your academic/reserach topic or you gained knowledge that will be useful in your studies/research then include it in the SOGP. This will strengthen the (This is what I am interested in - This is what I have accomplished so far - This is why Fulbright is the best opportunity to further my career goals) pitch.

If your international experience is not directly related to the topic/theme of your SOGP then put it in the personal statement. The reality is that living abroad is no small feat. Many times the degree program is the least of your worries. The selection committee wants to ensure that all grantees will last the duration of the grant and it can be useful to discuss how you handled any difficulties while living abroad.Â 

Do I need a letter of affiliation? How do I get one?

Definitely visit the official website and look at the specific grant information. This may vary by country and Award. However, the information below might be accurate for most study grants in the UK.

  1. A letter of affiliation can be either a letter of admission or a letter of acceptance. Both can be accepted for review with the application, as an applicant can submit up to three letters of affiliation. If an applicant does not have a letter of admission, but wishes to add a letter from a department or professor specifically supporting their project they can add that.
  2. You are correct, admission to a university is required for final receipt of the Fulbright award. A letter of admission is not required at the time of application, but can be accepted, and must be presented in order to receive the award.
  3. A letter of affiliation is not needed, however, both a letter of affiliation or admittance does strengthen an applicantâ€™s application.
  4. All letters of affiliation or admittance are reviewed by the National Screening Committees if they are received prior to October 8th. Further, if a candidate is moved on to semi-finalist status, any letters submitted with their application as well as any received in the interim can be reviewed by the UK Commission. Any letters can strengthen an applicantâ€™s application, but there is no disadvantage for not having one either.

How do you get one? Many times this involves reaching out directly to faculty or program directors via emails found on the university website.

One of my largest concerns is feeling like I am not good enough for the program and it is making writing my application difficult. What was your process for writing your application and what did you highlight that made you a stand out.Â 

Â 
I appreciate your honesty and directness. Trust me you are not alone. Even those who receive a Fulbright wonder how they got it.
Â 
Focus on what you are passionate about and build a story around it. For example, I began with a little story about the small "businesses" I started as a kid (lemonade/crafts/lawncare) and how that tied into what I wanted to do with my career....and more importantly why the Fulbright was the best opportunity to achieve those career goals. Passion, competency, and a bit of blissful ignorance about the competition can make a great start to an application.
Â 
Be prepared to revise your application A LOT. I revised my application countless times with aÂ Fulbright Program AdvisorÂ (may want to check in with your undergrad university, unless you are applying "at-large"). I also did not get the Fulbright the first time I applied for it. I know a few others have the same story.
Â 
Definitely check out some of theÂ Fulbright webinarsÂ on application content. They often have Fulbright alumni talk about their applications.

Have you encountered any positives or negatives aboutÂ pursuing and receivingÂ a Master's degree abroad, as opposed to staying within the U.S.?Â 

Outside of Oxford and Cambridge (and maybe London School of Economics), I have found that there is very little name recognition for other globally ranked universities across the American business world (the opposite is true for the academic world). Ultimately, there is immense value in getting a Master's degree abroad from a well ranked university. Given the opportunity to redo everything, I would quickly pick the Fulbright and UCL degree over a Harvard MBA any day.

Did you talk about specificÂ courses or professors that interested you within the program?Â 

Yes! Including this can help you to answer the question - [Why do you need to do this research/degree in this country at this university?] The MSc. Entrepreneurship at UCL is quite special because it essentially acts as a talent incubator. The program is set up to help students start and grow scalable companies, which was a core proposal in my SOGP. This is quite different from how MIT or Harvard structure their MBA programs. So, it offered a clear reason why UCL was one of the best, if not the best place, to pursue my goals.

Did you specify in your Statement of Grant Purpose yourÂ intended dissertation on public transportation, or was that something you developed while studying at UCL?

Great question. I actually proposed another project in my SOGP focused on building a decentralized, crowd-sourced emergency response service. However, my focus changed to the rail industry quite quickly once I started classes and assessed my opportunities. For an MSc. in Entrepreneurship this is somewhat normal (to pivot). However, for more technical degrees it is more uncommon to drastically deviate from your SOGP proposal.

In what ways did London add or detract from your experience at UCL?Â 

I think London is one of the best cities to get an MBA or any other graduate business degree. The access to people, companies, and money is unrivaled by most other cities in the world. A major downside of living in London is cost. I practiced frugality the majority of my time while Fulbright peers in other UK cities (and other countries) were not as concerned on budgeting based on my personal experience.

For Host Country Engagement, did you focus on ways to get involved within the UCL campus or with London in general? In what ways did you end up engaging with the community?Â 

There are two main points that need to be made in the Host Country Engagement response.

  1. How will you act as an ambassador outside of your research/studies?
  2. How will you develop a support structure to cope with difficult circumstances?

From my experience, I think some of the best strategies rely on engaging through your passions/interests whether that is sport, music, art, food, etc. That could take the form of being involved with UCL or University of London student groups, however it could also take almost any other form. London is special because the opportunities are seemingly endless and a community can be found for even the most esoteric interests.

Again, I think the MSc. Entrepreneurship is a bit different because of the networking requirements of the program itself. I spent what felt like a majority of my time meeting with local entrepreneurs, engineers, designers, and investors. I also participated in hackathons and coding challenges. I think I originally proposed getting involved in a football club and volunteering at a local community kitchen, but my schedule prevented me from doing either of those things.

Any other tips or tricks?

  1. Start early (6-7 months).
  2. Revise, revise, revise!
  3. Stay strong even when success seems unlikely.

I did not start the application process with extremely concrete and succinct ideas of why I wanted to pursue a Fulbright Award. While I was fortunate to intern abroad at engineering companies in Seoul and Bangalore, I spent much of my undergraduate career with my nose in an engineering textbook or prepping for an exam. I did not take enough time to really think about and plan my 5/10 years goals. The application process really helped me to slow down and carefully think about myself and my goals, which really required months of time to solidify.

I did not get the Fulbright Award the first time I applied because I bombed the UK Commission interview. However, by that point I already convinced myself that the Fulbright-UCL Award really was the perfect opportunity. I applied again, gained better insight into the interview, and was fortunate to receive the award the second time.

General Thoughts

  1. Describing the distinctions in your field between the U.S. and U.K. shows competence and effort. If you can describe, as you just did, whyÂ  Kent is the best place to achieve your career goals (or follow your interests) then this will greatly enhance the strength of the application.
  2. Being able to succinctly describe your field of interest to a group of laypeople while still maintaining the interest of experts is key. Your application will undergo at least two levels of review; the first by a selection committee that will most likely be familiar with your field and the second by the U.K. commission that will not be familiar with your field. If you can keep the reader's interest/respect then you can tie it in with your career goals and make them excited about the impact you could have in the world given the Fulbright.
  3. Being able to succinctly describe your field and interests also reflects on your communication capabilities, which in turn reflects on your ability to be a good cultural ambassador. For example, while in the UK you may find yourself trying to explain race inequality, firearms, politics, and police brutality more often than expected.

Â

entry.title: Why Food Sucks
entry.summary: Just a few generations ago my great grandparents tended to their family farm after immigrating to the United States from…
entry.content:
Just a few generations ago my great grandparents tended to their family farm after immigrating to the United States from Poland. Back then, more than half of Americans were living in rural farming communities. These farmers grew a variety of crops and raised a variety of animals. Preservation techniques like fermentation, drying, and smoking were still common and had been passed between generations over thousands of years.

I never got to meet my great grandparents. I did not grow up plucking carrots from a field. I did not chase a chicken for dinner. I grew up eating fried lumps of ground chicken trimmings that were neatly packaged in a cardboard container and served with a side of flavored corn syrup sauce.

There is growing criticism of the current industrialized food system. Chronic disease and ecological destruction follow in the wake of so called "market demands". Popular social opinion often points to one of many causes including overpopulation, food waste, or unchecked capitalism. The reality is more complicated.

However, a number of visionaries are currently rethinking what our food system needs to look like in the next 20 years to meet population, health, and lifestyle demands. From vertical and shipping container farming to suburban permaculture oases, there are a number of efforts to re-balance the food system for the health of humans and the environment.

Hyper-local food production is a potential solution to many of the problems the plague our food system.

Over the past year I have designed, engineered, and tested a personal food growing device for urban dwellers. I think this grow system should be available to everyone which is why I have open-sourced the design on Github. This is the first article in a three part series.

  1. Why Food Sucks | A Dangerously Short Overview of Industrialized Agriculture
  2. The Future of Food is Hyper-local | A Promising Vision for the Future of Agriculture
  3. How to Never Kill another Plant | Building a Personal Automated Nano Farm

First, I find that most people I talk to, including my family, have little idea how food ends up on their plate or in their mouth. What problems have been created by agricultural industrialization and how does hyper-local food production attempt to solve them?

Consolidation of Agriculture

How many farmers do you know today? How many different sub species or cultivars of bananas have you eaten?

Over the last century, industrialization has pushed the majority of food production into the hands of fewer and fewer farms which produce fewer and fewer varieties of plants and animals. According to statistics from the USDA, the number of farms in the U.S. has decreased from approximately seven million in 1935 to approximately two million today.

There are still two million farms, which is more than you might expect. However, the centralization of production volume is another story. Ninety percent of farms only account for twenty percent of production. Large scale farms make up only three percent of farms, but account for forty-six percent of total production value.

Yet, farms are not where the majority of power consolidation has occurred. The alarming consolidation is in seed production where a handful of chemical and pharmaceutical corporations control the market for many crops. Corporations like Dow, DuPont, and Bayer (acquired Monsanto) sell seeds because they can (and do) make killer profits from selling pesticides and other complimentary chemical products. The USDA published a report in 2004 that details this consolidation. Similar analysis can be drawn for livestock production.

The main point is that U.S. agriculture has consolidated to the point of concern, in my opinion. However, there is obviously more sides to the story. With consolidation comes optimization and the optimization is quite impressive.

From an engineering perspective, industrial agriculture is an absolute marvel of modern process design, mechanization, and logistics.

Hundreds of millions of people are being fed with a minimal amount of human time and effort. People can now spend more of their time on entertainment, relaxation, or investigating some of life's most interesting questions. Johns Hopkins has a great overview the industrialization of food production and it effects including distribution and waste.

Â 

Why Food Sucks

Again from a system and engineering point of view, food production is a process to be optimized to increase profit. This has led to plants/animals that are cultivated and engineered for

  • high yield
  • mechanized harvest
  • transportation
  • selling (tangible appearance and shelf life)

While not inherently bad, these optimization variables have unintended consequences that result from incomplete scientific understanding and misaligned economic incentives. These consequences manifest in the form of

  • mono-culture and reduced genetic variety
  • chemical and pharmaceutical use
  • food waste
  • habitat destruction and desertification
  • increased reliance on highly processed foods

Each of these topics are a book, or a series of book unto themselves. References will be added at the end of this articles as my time allows. The main point is that

Food is at the heart of many modern crises including chronic disease and environmental destruction. Systemic changes to food production and consumption are needed.

How to Make Food Not Suck

The good news is that we are in the middle of an agricultural revolution. There are startups working on a huge range of ideas;

  • creating meat/protein alternatives
  • using crops for carbon capture and storage
  • reducing chemical use by surveying with drone and satellite imagery
  • creating more efficient food marketplaces

Some of these efforts seek to make the current system work better while others are on a quest of systemic disruption. One such systemic disrupter is the growing field of hydroponics and the business model of hyper-local produce production. Hydroponics, also known in the U.S. as soilless culture, is enabling food producers to grow food closer to where it is consumed, all while using less resources and pesticides.

Â 
In part two of this series, The Future of Food is Hyper-local | A Promising Vision for the Future of Agriculture, I delve into the proposed benefits of hyper-local food production and the science behind it.
Â 
Part 2
Â

02/09/2020 - Added USDA statistics and resources on agricultural consolidation
